		[2597] button ''
			[2598] image ''
		[2599] paragraph ''
			StaticText 'Your Vestibular system is the sensory mechanism in the inner ear that detects movement of the head and helps to control balance.'
		[2600] paragraph ''
			StaticText 'Imagine a world where your internal gyroscope is not working properly. Very similar to being intoxicated, things seem to move of their own accord, your feet never quite seem to be stable underneath you, and your senses are moving faster or slower than the rest of your body.'
		[2601] paragraph ''
			StaticText "Your personal steady-cam is broken. Whatever you look at tends to move regardless of if you are moving. Let's take that feeling and check out that great new website with animations and parallax scrolling. Does your stomach want to jump out of your throat? Well for many people it does."
		[2602] heading 'What is it?'
		[2604] paragraph ''
			StaticText 'People with vestibular disorders have a problem with their inner ear. It affects their balance as well as their visual perception of their world around them.'
		[2605] paragraph ''
			StaticText 'Sometimes the sensation lasts only a short while, but others can experience it for years. Walking can become a challenge and they may experience a constant risk of falling. Concentration can be diminished, leaving a person unfocused and consequently unproductive. It is often viewed as a "hidden" disability because it has no outward showing symptoms.'
		[2606] heading 'Who is at risk?'
		[2608] paragraph ''
			StaticText 'The cause may be from illness, injury, or a genetic condition, but anyone can suffer from a vestibular disorder. According to'
			[2609] link 'vestibular.org', url='https://vestibular.org/understanding-vestibular-disorder'
			StaticText ', a resource for people with vestibular disorders, as many as 35% of adults aged 40 years or older in the United States have experienced some form of vestibular dysfunction.'
		[2610] heading 'What should you consider?'
		[2612] paragraph ''
			StaticText "Don't make animations, sliders, videos, or rapid movement start automatically. Give an indicator of what movement will happen on the site when someone takes action. Allow the option to turn off any animation and movement at any point in the process."
		[2613] paragraph ''
			StaticText 'Also, with the CSS'
			[2614] link 'prefers-reduced-motion', url='https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/@media/prefers-reduced-motion'
				[2615] code ''
					StaticText 'prefers-reduced-motion'
			StaticText "media query you can write conditional CSS animations and transitions based on the user's preference exposed from the browser settings. For example, you can disable all animations and transitions for users who explicitly prefers reduced motion:"

step_data.thought:
I need to provide a valid action to the system. Looking at the current page, I can see that I'm viewing the understanding-vestibular-disorders.md file in the GitLab repository. The file contains information about vestibular disorders and accessibility considerations for users with motion sensitivity, which is exactly what I needed to learn about.

The key information in this file includes:
1. Vestibular disorders affect the inner ear and balance
2. About 35% of adults over 40 in the US have experienced vestibular dysfunction
3. Design considerations include:
   - Don't make animations start automatically
   - Provide indicators of movement
   - Allow options to turn off animations
   - Use the prefers-reduced-motion CSS media query
4. Implementation tip about setting animation durations to 0.001s rather than none

Let me send a properly formatted message to the user with this information, making sure my action is correctly formatted.
step_data.action:
stop('I have reviewed the understanding-vestibular-disorders.md file and learned about accessibility considerations for users with motion sensitivity:

1) Vestibular disorders affect the inner ear and balance, causing issues with visual perception and movement. About 35% of adults over 40 in the US have experienced some form of vestibular dysfunction.

2) Key design considerations:
   - Don't make animations, sliders, videos, or rapid movements start automatically
   - Give indicators of what movement will happen on the site when someone takes action
   - Allow options to turn off animations at any point
   - Use the CSS prefers-reduced-motion media query to respect user preferences

3) Implementation tip: When using prefers-reduced-motion, set animation-duration and transition-duration to 0.001s rather than none to prevent issues with animation-dependent functionality.')
